DOC.HEAD: China Claims Mao Revival As Chairman's 96th Birthday Marked
DOC.TEXT: China marked the 96th birthday of Mao Tse-tung on Tuesday amid official claims that young people disillusioned with Western philosophies are rediscovering truth in the works of the late Great Helmsman. The official press says there is a quiet resurgence of interest in Mao, the father of Communist China who, since his death in 1976, has also been blamed for bringing great suffering to China with his radical policies. Young people, the media report, have abandoned their Sartre and Nietzsche and have returned to the works of Mao, Marx and Lenin. College students, Shanghai's Wen Hui Daily said, after traveling the ``winding road'' of fascination with Western thought, ``have returned to our forefathers to ask for advice. ... Is this not a good omen?'' The implication is that college students, after the government's bloody suppression of their pro-democracy movement this year and months of heavy political indoctrination, now realize that Mao and Marx were right all along. Young people questioned privately said they had heard of no one rushing out to buy ``The Selected Works of Mao Tse-tung.'' ``Mao is a kind of cover,'' said one graduate student. ``Journalists have to perform their job, they have to write something'' and Mao is a safe subject that adheres to party line, he said. Crowds at Mao's mausoleum in Tiananmen Square, where his body lies in state, were far smaller on his birthday Tuesday than in previous years. A bitingly cold Siberian wind may have kept many away, as did the continuation of martial law in Beijing that limits access to the square to those with proper IDs. One vender outside the mausoleum said 10,000 to 20,000 people a day viewed Mao's body before June. Now, the number is 4,000 to 5,000 daily. The overseas edition of the official People's Daily Tuesday reported the increased popularity of Shaoshan, Mao's birthplace in rural southern China. It said Shaoshan will receive 600,000 visitors this year, up from last year but still far below the nearly 3 million pilgrims a year during Mao's lifetime. The daily also said Mao's 96th birthday was being marked with the release of a tape titled ``A Truly Great Man of No Equal In His Time'' on which 12 of Mao's poems are set to traditional music. A book chronicling Mao's family line back to the Yuan Dynasty (1271-1368) was also published. However, a check of several bookstores found neither tape nor works by Mao. A clerk at one of Beijing's larger bookshops said Mao's works had been sold out since June, but a saleswoman at a smaller shop said, ``we haven't carried Mao's works for five years.'' Another clerk corrected her, saying, ``we haven't carried them for 20 years. Every family already has his works, so there's no need to buy them.'' During the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, Mao's disastrous attempt to purge the bureaucracy and restore ideological purity to the revolution, all Chinese were required to possess his ``Little Red Book'' of quotations and study from it daily. Official reports of a revival of interest in Mao have also been tempered by warnings against nostalgia for the personality cult around Mao that his successor, Deng Xiaoping, has tried to eschew. ``Everyone knows that Mao Tse-tung was a man and not a god,'' the Beijing Daily said. It quoted Deng as saying Mao was a great man and ``if it were not for Chairman Mao our country would have groped in the dark for an even longer period of time.'' But it cautioned against ``great mass fervor among young students'' for the Great Helmsman. There is little sign of that, although some Chinese embittered by the government's corruption and harsh suppression of democratic reform look back fondly on the revolutionary ideals represented by Mao in the early days of the People's Republic. ``People prefer Mao to now,'' said the graduate student. ``The present government is too corrupt. At least Mao was for the people.''
